DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower; Gold Mixed
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar tumbled Friday in abbreviated pre-Christmas foreign-exchange trading, weighed down by continuing demand for the West German mark and expectations that U.S. interest rates are headed lower. Gold prices edged higher in New York after turning in a mixed performance overseas. Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid for a troy ounce of gold at $413.75 as of 1 p.m. EST, up from $412.20 late Thursday. Traders said the dollar was little affected by the continuing U.S. intervention in Panama and the fall Friday of Nicolae Ceausescu, the long-time Romanian leader. The currency markets finished the trading day at around midday, several hours earlier than normal as traders got a headstart on the three-day holiday weekend. ``The dollar traded in a range early and fell off late in the session,'' said Jeff Mondschein, managing director of foreign exchange for Continental Bank in Chicago. But he cautioned against reading much into the decline, saying trading was so light that a few orders were all that was needed to move the market. The underlying factors that have affected the dollar for the past few days _ a weakening U.S. economy and the expectation that interest rates are headed lower _ continued to depress the currency, Mondschein said. Falling interest rates hurt the dollar by cutting yields foreigners can get on dollar-denominated investments. In Europe, dealers said the dollar was hurt by the strength of the mark and said that as the dollar fell below the 1.7250-mark level, dealers who had instructions from some customers to sell dollars at that level began executing those orders. But trading activity also was curtailed in Europe, as most major banks cut the trading day short in advance of the Christmas holiday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 Japanese yen to close at 143.67 yen. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 143.05 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 142.35 yen from 143.65 yen late Thursday. The dollar also lost ground against the British pound. In London, the pound rose to $1.6205 from $1.6125 late Thursday. Sterling rose to $1.62425 in New York from $1.6145 late Thursday. Selected dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.7070 West German marks, down from 1.7260; 1.5490 Swiss francs, down from 1.5580; 5.8345 French francs, down from 5.8910; 1,277.75 Italian lire, down from 1,285.50; and 1.1592 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1597. Other afternoon dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.7090 West German marks, down from 1.7250; 1.5475 Swiss francs, down from 1.5575; 5.8385 French francs, down from 5.8955; 1.9330 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9560; 1,277.75 Italian lire, down from 1,287.50; and 1.1585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1605. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $1.30 a troy ounce to $413.20. Earlier, gold fell to a late bid of $412.25 a troy ounce in London, down from $412.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, Switzerland, the metal finished at $413 an ounce for the third session in a row. Gold rose 33 cents in Hong Kong to close at $411.69 an ounce. Silver rose 1.7 cents a troy ounce to $5.560 on the Comex in New York. Silver rose in London to a late bid of $5.58 a troy ounce from Thursday's $5.57.
